title: 109_s1411
content: The Act is titled the "National Small Business Regulatory Assistance Act of 2005" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "National Small Business Regulatory Assistance Act of 2005" establishes a 4-year pilot program to provide confidential assistance, information on regulatory compliance, create partnerships among Federal agencies, offer unbiased feedback, and expand services for small business development centers. SEC. 3. SMALL BUSINESS REGULATORY ASSISTANCE PILOT PROGRAM. The definitions in this section clarify terms like Administration, Administrator, Association, and participating Small Business Development Center for the pilot program. The Administrator will establish a pilot program to provide regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses in various states and territories. The Administrator will establish a pilot program with Small Business Development Centers to provide regulatory compliance assistance to small businesses. Centers will offer access to information, resources, training, and one-on-one assistance. Small Business Development Centers offer free counseling, technical assistance, referrals to experts, and form partnerships with Federal compliance programs for small business owners regarding regulatory compliance. Small Business Development Centers partner with Federal compliance programs and provide regulatory compliance assistance to small business concerns. Quarterly reports are submitted to the Administrator and the Chief Counsel for Advocacy of the Small Business Administration, detailing the assistance provided, the number of businesses helped, and any regulatory compliance information received from Federal or State agencies. Small Business Development Centers partner with Federal compliance programs to provide assistance to small businesses. Centers must be certified under the Small Business Act to receive assistance. The Administrator selects Centers from different states to participate in the pilot program. Maine is part of Group 1 for selection. Group 1 includes Maine, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Connecticut, Vermont, and Rhode Island. Group 2 consists of New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico, and the Virgin Islands. Group 3 includes Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, Virginia, the District of Columbia, and Delaware. Group 4 consists of Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina, South Carolina, Mississippi, Florida, Kentucky, and Tennessee. Group 5 includes Illinois, Ohio, Michigan, Indiana, Wisconsin, and Minnesota. Group 6 consists of Texas, New Mexico, Arkansas, Oklahoma, and Louisiana. The Administrator will select groups of states for a pilot program within 60 days of final regulations. Matching requirements from the Small Business Act apply to assistance under the program. The pilot program established under this section provides grants to State programs, with amounts ranging from $150,000 to $300,000 per fiscal year. The Comptroller General will evaluate the program within 30 months of the first grant disbursement and submit a report to relevant committees within 6 months of the evaluation. The House of Representatives will receive a report on the evaluation of a pilot program and any recommendations for its extension to include all Small Business Development Centers. $5 million is authorized for the first fiscal year after enactment, with the same amount for the following 3 years. The Administrator is limited to using these funds for the pilot program. The Small Business Regulatory Assistance Pilot Program can only be carried out with appropriated funds and will terminate 4 years after the first grant disbursement. SEC. 4. RULEMAKING. After notice, comment, and consultation with the association, the Administrator will establish regulations for the pilot program under this Act, including priorities for assistance, standards for services by Small Business Development Centers, national service delivery standards, work plan requirements, and educational standards. Standards for the competency of experts or assistance providers referred to small businesses under the pilot program will be established.
